785786_14_ITEM5_P4_S4	Accordingly, since this program became effective subsequent to September 27, 2014 , the $30.0 million authorization is excluded from the table above.
785786_14_ITEM6_P0_S0	(1) During fiscal 2014, the Company recorded $11.3 million in restructuring and impairment charges, which are included in operating income.
785786_14_ITEM6_P0_S1	These charges largely related to the Company's consolidation of its facilities in the Fox Cities (Neenah and Appleton), Wisconsin, as well as its relocation of manufacturing operations from Juarez, Mexico to a new manufacturing facility in Guadalajara, Mexico.
785786_14_ITEM6_P1_S0	(2) The Company defines return on invested capital as tax-effected operating income divided by average invested capital over a rolling five-quarter period.
785786_14_ITEM6_P2_S0	(3) In fiscal 2012, the Company established a valuation allowance against its U.S. deferred tax assets resulting in an additional tax provision of approximately $20.6 million ($22.8 million provision, offset by $2.2 million to other comprehensive income) and a decrease in diluted earnings per share of $0.64.
785786_14_ITEM6_P2_S1	Return on invested capital excludes the $20.6 million net deferred tax asset reduction.
785786_14_ITEM6_P2_S2	An additional $1.3 million of valuation allowance established for fiscal 2012 relates to operating losses in Germany and Romania making the total valuation allowance for that year $24.1 million.
785786_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	OVERVIEW Plexus Corp. and its subsidiaries (together Plexus, the Company, or "we") participate in the Electronic Manufacturing Services ( EMS ) industry.
785786_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	We deliver optimized solutions to our customers through our unique Product Realization Value Stream.
785786_14_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our customer-focused solutions model seamlessly integrates innovative product conceptualization, design, commercialization, manufacturing, fulfillment and sustaining solutions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	Plexus delivers comprehensive end-to-end solutions for customers in the Americas ( AMER ), Europe, Middle East, and Africa ( EMEA ) and Asia-Pacific ( APAC ) regions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	We provide award-winning customer service to more than 140 branded product companies in the Networking/Communications, Healthcare/Life Sciences, Industrial/Commercial and Defense/Security/Aerospace market sectors.
785786_14_ITEM7_P1_S2	Our customers have stringent quality, reliability and regulatory requirements, requiring exceptional production and supply chain agility.
785786_14_ITEM7_P1_S3	Their products require complex configuration management, direct order fulfillment (to end customers) and global logistics management and aftermarket services.
785786_14_ITEM7_P1_S4	To service the complexities that our customers' products demand, we utilize our Product Realization Value Stream, addressing our customers' products from concept to end of life.
785786_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	The following information should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included herein and Risk Factors included in Part I, Item 1A herein.
785786_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	Recent Developments We opened our new manufacturing facility in Guadalajara, Mexico during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	This facility is replacing our existing facility in Juarez, Mexico, which will be closed during the first quarter of fiscal 2015.
785786_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	This transition resulted in approximately $7.0 million of restructuring and impairment charges during fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P3_S3	Closure of the facility in Juarez is expected to result in approximately $1.5 to $1.8 million of additional restructuring charges in the first quarter of fiscal 2015.
785786_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	We opened our new manufacturing facility in Neenah, Wisconsin during the first quarter of fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	This facility consolidated one owned and two leased facilities in the Fox Cities (Neenah and Appleton), Wisconsin.
785786_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	The consolidation of these facilities resulted in approximately $4.3 million of restructuring charges during fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Consolidated Performance Summary.
785786_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	The following table presents selected consolidated financial data for fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 (dollars in millions, except per share data):
785786_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2014 increased $150.2 million, or 6.7 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	The net sales increase was primarily the result of a $134.1 million increase in net sales in the healthcare/life sciences sector, as well as net sales increases in the industrial/commercial and defense/security/aerospace sectors, partially offset by a reduction in net sales in the networking/communication sector.
785786_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	headwind related to the disengagement of Juniper Networks, Inc. ("Juniper") in fiscal 2013, partially offset by a $230.3 million increase in net sales to two key customers in that sector primarily resulting from new product ramps.
785786_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	Net sales for fiscal 2013 decreased $78.7 million, or 3.4 percent, as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P7_S2	The net sales decrease was primarily the result of a $113.6 million decrease in net sales for one of our larger customers in the industrial/commercial sector, as a result of its decreased end-market demand, as well as an $85.3 million decrease in net sales to Juniper as a result of its disengagement and lower end-market demand for the products we formerly produced for Juniper.
785786_14_ITEM7_P7_S3	These decreases were partially offset by a $102.4 million increase in net sales to various significant customers in all sectors.
785786_14_ITEM7_P7_S4	Our net sales by market sector for fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 were as follows (in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the networking/communications sector decreased $63.8 million, or 7.7 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	The change was primarily the result of a $282.6 million decrease in net sales to Juniper, related to its disengagement, partially offset by a $230.3 million increase in sales related to two key customers in this sector primarily resulting from new program ramps.
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the networking/communications sector decreased $77.3 million as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S3	The change was primarily the result of an $85.3 million decrease in net sales to Juniper, related to its disengagement, partially offset by increased sales to existing customers in this sector as well as program ramps with new customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S4	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the healthcare/life sciences sector increased $134.1 million, or 23.8 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P8_S5	The increase was primarily due to $89.3 million of new program ramps and increased end-market demand for two key customers in this sector and increased end-market demand and new program ramps across several other customers in this sector.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the healthcare/life sciences sector increased $68.8 million as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	The increase was primarily due to market share gains and new program ramps with existing customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the industrial/commercial sector increased $32.5 million, or 5.9 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S3	The increase was primarily the result of the expansion of current business with one of our larger customers in the sector, which accounted for $30.7 million of the increased net sales as compared to the prior year.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S4	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the industrial/commercial sector decreased $119.8 million as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S5	The decrease was primarily a result of decreased end-market demand for one of our larger customers in the sector, which accounted for $113.6 million of the decreased net sales as compared to the prior year.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S6	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the defense/security/aerospace sector increased $47.4 million, or 16.5 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S7	The increase was primarily due to $37.5 million resulting from new program ramps and increased end-market demand for one of our larger customers in the sector.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S8	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the defense/security/aerospace sector increased $49.6 million as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P9_S9	The increase was the result of new program ramps as well as increased end-market demand for the products we produce for our customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	As a percentage of consolidated net sales, net sales attributable to customers representing 10.0 percent or more of consolidated net sales as well as the percentage of net sales attributable to our ten largest customers for fiscal 2014, 2013 and 2012, were as follows:
785786_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	Gross profit for fiscal 2014 increased $ 12.4 million , or 5.8 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	Overall gross margin decreased to 9.5 percent from 9.6 percent.
785786_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	Gross profit increased $34.2 million primarily as a result of increased sales.
785786_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	This favorable effect was largely offset by a $21.9 million increase in fixed costs due to our investment in a new manufacturing facility in Neenah, Wisconsin, the ramp up of new business in the AMER region, and increased depreciation and personnel expenses with our new manufacturing facility in Oradea, Romania.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	Gross profit for fiscal 2013 decreased $6.7 million, or 3.1 percent, as compared to fiscal 2012 primarily due to decreased net sales, increased fixed expenses related to site investments in Penang, Malaysia, Xiamen, China, and Oradea, Romania, and unfavorable changes in customer mix.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	The decrease was partially offset by the sale of certain inventory that had previously been written down.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	A slightly larger percentage decrease in revenue as compared to the decrease in gross profit for fiscal 2013 led to an increase in gross margin to 9.6 percent for fiscal 2013 from 9.5 percent for fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	Operating income for fiscal 2014 increased $ 4.0 million as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S4	A $2.9 million decrease in selling and administrative expenses ("S A") as compared to prior year and the previously discussed increase to gross profit were partially offset by $11.3 million of restructuring and impairment charges primarily related to the consolidation of facilities in the Fox Cities, Wisconsin, and the relocation of manufacturing operations from Juarez, Mexico, to Guadalajara, Mexico.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S5	As a result, operating margin decreased to 4.2 percent for fiscal 2014 from 4.3 percent for fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S6	Operating income for fiscal 2013 decreased $7.5 million as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S7	The operating income decrease reflected the $6.7 million decrease in gross profit described above as well as a $0.8 million increase in S A expenses.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S8	The increase in S A was primarily due to approximately $2.4 million of recoveries of receivables previously at risk in the prior fiscal year, with no such recovery in the current fiscal year, and approximately $0.8 million of additional amortization expense in fiscal 2013 related to the Kontron arrangement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S9	These increases were partially offset by a $1.3 million decrease in incentive compensation expense and additional reductions due to focused cost management efforts.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S10	As a result of the factors discussed above, for fiscal 2013 compared to fiscal 2012, operating margin decreased from 4.5 percent to 4.3 percent.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S11	Other expense for fiscal 2014 decreased $ 4.4 million as compared to fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S12	The decrease in other expense for fiscal 2014 was primarily the result of a $1.3 million increase in interest income, a $1.1 million decrease in currency exchange losses, a $0.8 million decrease in miscellaneous expense due to a favorable outcome related to a previous accrual for expenses related to the termination of an agreement for additional land in Hangzhou, China, and a $0.3 million decrease in interest expense.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S13	Other expense decreased to $11.6 million for fiscal 2013 from $12.9 million for fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P12_S14	The decrease in expense was largely due to $3.4 million of decreased interest expense related to our former term loan.
785786_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	Interest rate swaps associated with the original term loan expired in fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	This resulted in lower floating interest rates prior to the establishment of a new interest rate swap agreement and lower fixed interest rates subsequent to the establishment of the new interest rate swap agreement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	This decrease was offset by a $1.4 million increase in foreign exchange losses and a $0.8 million increase in other expense as the result of an accrual for property-related expenses related to the termination of an agreement for additional land in Hangzhou, China.
785786_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	Income tax expense and effective annual income tax rates, with and without the annual valuation allowance, for fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 were as follows (dollars in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	*The Company believes that the non-GAAP presentation of income tax (benefit) expense and effective annual tax rate excluding the impact of the valuation allowance provides a more meaningful comparison of reporting periods.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Income tax expense for fiscal 2014 was $6.1 million compared to $2.7 million for fiscal 2013 and $29.1 million for fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	The Company's effective annual tax rates vary from the U.S. statutory rate of 35.0% primarily as a result of the mix of earnings from U.S. and foreign jurisdictions and tax holidays granted to subsidiaries located in the APAC region where the Company derives a significant portion of its earnings.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	The effective tax rate for fiscal 2014 was higher than the effective rate for fiscal 2013 primarily as a result of the geographic distribution of worldwide earnings.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S3	The effective tax rate for fiscal 2013 was significantly lower than the effective tax rate in fiscal 2012 primarily due to the amount of the additional valuation allowance recorded in fiscal 2012 on deferred tax assets in the U.S. as well as discrete tax benefits recorded in fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S4	In fiscal 2014, the Company recorded a $7.9 million addition to its valuation allowance relating to continuing losses in certain jurisdictions within the AMER and EMEA regions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S5	At the close of fiscal 2014, using the measurement criteria found in ASC Topic 740, Income Taxes ("ASC 740"), the Company believes that the positive evidence does not outweigh the negative and the valuation allowance should remain in place.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S6	During fiscal 2014, the Company also recorded tax benefits of $3.8 million primarily related to the lapse of statutes of limitations related to U.S. tax examinations during the fiscal year.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S7	In fiscal 2013, the Company recorded a $7.0 million addition to its valuation allowance, of which $5.2 million related to continuing losses certain jurisdictions within the AMER and EMEA regions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S8	During fiscal 2013, the Company performed an analysis of all available evidence, both positive and negative, regarding the need for a valuation allowance against its U.K. deferred tax assets, consistent with the provisions of ASC 740.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S9	Accordingly, the Company established an additional $1.8 million valuation allowance against the U.K. deferred tax assets.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S10	During fiscal 2013 the Company also identified and recorded several out-of-period tax errors that reduced tax expense by $3.2 million.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S11	The Company believes these out-of-period tax errors were not material to the fiscal 2013, or previously issued, financial statements.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S12	In fiscal 2012, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of $24.1 million, of which $1.3 million related to continuing losses in certain jurisdictions within the EMEA region.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S13	During the preparation of the fiscal 2012 consolidated financial statements, the Company performed an analysis of all available evidence, both positive and negative, regarding the need for a valuation allowance against its U.S. deferred tax assets, consistent with the provisions of ASC 740.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S14	Accordingly, the Company established an additional $22.8 million valuation allowance against its U.S. deferred tax assets.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S15	The Company has been granted a tax holiday for a foreign subsidiary operating in the APAC region.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S16	This tax holiday will expire in fiscal 2024 and is subject to certain conditions with which the Company expects to comply.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S17	The Company benefited from a second tax holiday within the APAC region until December 31, 2013, when it expired under the terms of the Company's agreement with the local taxing authority.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S18	The expiration of this holiday did not have a material impact on the Company s effective tax rate or results of operations.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S19	In fiscal 2014, 2013, and 2012, these holidays resulted in tax reductions of approximately $24.1 million ($0.71 per basic share), $22.7 million ($0.66 per basic share), and $17.5 million ($0.50 per basic share), respectively.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S20	We currently expect the annual effective tax rate for fiscal 2015 to be approximately 8.0 to 10.0 percent.
785786_14_ITEM7_P16_S21	Net income, both including and excluding the annual valuation allowance and out-of-period tax adjustments, for fiscal 2014, 2013 and 2012 was as follows (dollars in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	*The Company believes that the non-GAAP presentation of net income excluding valuation allowances and out-of-period tax adjustments provides a more meaningful comparison of reporting periods.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	Net income for fiscal 2014 increased $5.0 million, or 6.0 percent, to $87.2 million from fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	Net income increased primarily as a result of increased gross profit and lower S A expenses, partially offset by increased restructuring and impairment charges and increased income tax expense, as discussed previously.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	Net income for fiscal 2013 increased $20.2 million, or 32.5 percent, to $82.3 million from fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S3	This increase was primarily as a result of the net $17.1 million year-over-year valuation allowance adjustment.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S4	Excluding the valuation allowance and fourth quarter fiscal 2013 tax out-of-period adjustments, fiscal 2013 net income decreased by $0.1 million, or 0.1 percent, from fiscal 2012 to $86.1 million.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S5	Diluted earnings per share increased to $2.52, or 6.8 percent, for fiscal 2014 from $2.36 for fiscal 2013 primarily as a result of increased net income.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S6	Further improvement was due to the positive impact of fewer outstanding shares in 2014 due to our common stock repurchase program.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S7	These improvements were offset by restructuring and impairment costs.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S8	See Note 14, "Shareholders' Equity" in Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information regarding the Company's stock repurchase programs.
785786_14_ITEM7_P18_S9	See Note 15, "Restructuring and Impairment Costs," in Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information regarding restructuring and impairment costs.
785786_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	Diluted earnings per share increased to $2.36, or 34.9 percent, for fiscal 2013 from $1.75 for fiscal 2012 primarily as a result of the impact of the valuation allowances and fiscal 2013 out-of-period tax adjustments discussed above.
785786_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	Excluding the impact of the valuation allowances and out-of-period tax adjustments, diluted earnings per share increased by $0.04 in fiscal 2013 as compared to fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P19_S2	The increase in diluted earnings per share, as adjusted was primarily due to the positive impact of fewer outstanding shares in 2013 due to the stock repurchase program.
785786_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	Return on Invested Capital ( ROIC ).
785786_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	We use a 5-5 financial model which is aligned with our business strategy, and includes a ROIC goal of 500 basis points over our weighted average cost of capital ( WACC ), which we refer to as economic return and a 5.0 percent operating margin target.
785786_14_ITEM7_P20_S2	Our primary focus is on our economic return goal of 5.0 percent, which is designed to create shareholder value and generate enough cash to self-fund our targeted organic revenue growth rate of 12.0 percent.
785786_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	We review our internal calculation of WACC annually.
785786_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	Our WACC was 11.0 percent, 12.0 percent, and 12.5 percent for fiscal 2014, 2013, and 2012, respectively.
785786_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	For fiscal 2015, our estimated WACC is 11.0 percent.
785786_14_ITEM7_P21_S3	By exercising discipline to generate ROIC in excess of our WACC, our goal is to create value for our shareholders.
785786_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	ROIC was 15.2 percent, 14.0 percent, and 15.5 percent (excluding a $20.6 million net deferred tax asset reduction) for fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
785786_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	The increase in ROIC in fiscal 2014 from fiscal 2013 was due to higher operating income, partially offset by the effect of an increase in average invested capital as a result of capital expenditures for facility expansions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	See the table below for our calculation of ROIC (dollars in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	We define ROIC as tax-effected operating income before restructuring and impairment charges divided by average invested capital over a rolling five-quarter period for the fiscal year.
785786_14_ITEM7_P23_S1	Invested capital is defined as equity plus debt, less cash and cash equivalents.
785786_14_ITEM7_P23_S2	Other companies may not define or calculate ROIC in the same way.
785786_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	ROIC and other non-GAAP financial measures should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, measures of our financial performance prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ).
785786_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	Non-GAAP financial measures, including ROIC, are used for internal management assessments because such measures provide additional insight into ongoing financial performance.
785786_14_ITEM7_P25_S1	In particular, we provide ROIC because we believe it offers insight into the metrics that are driving management decisions because we view ROIC as an important measure in evaluating the efficiency and effectiveness of our long-term capital requirements.
785786_14_ITEM7_P25_S2	We also use a derivative measure of ROIC as a performance criteria in determining certain elements of compensation.
785786_14_ITEM7_P25_S3	For a reconciliation of ROIC to our financial statements that were prepared using GAAP, see exhibit 99.1 to this annual report on Form 10-K, which exhibit is incorporated herein by reference.
785786_14_ITEM7_P25_S4	REPORTABLE SEGMENTS A further discussion of our fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 financial performance by reportable segment is presented below (in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the AMER segment increased $175.4 million, or 16.5 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013, primarily due to increased net sales of $154.8 million to a key networking/communications customer resulting from a new product ramp.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	Increased end-market demand and new product ramps on several of our larger customers across all four sectors drove further increased sales for fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	Partially offsetting these increases was a $115.8 million decrease in net sales from the disengagement of Juniper.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S3	Operating income for fiscal 2014 increased $4.0 million from fiscal 2013 due primarily to the increase in net sales.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S4	Excluding the impact of restructuring and impairment charges, operating income for fiscal 2014 increased $15.3 million from fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S5	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the AMER segment decreased $193.1 million, or 15.4 percent, from fiscal 2012, due primarily to $113.6 million of decreased sales resulting from lower end-market demand from a significant industrial/commercial sector customer as well as a $71.1 million decrease in net sales due to a drop in demand from Juniper related to its disengagement and lower end-market demand for the products we formerly produced for Juniper.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S6	Operating income for fiscal 2013 decreased $20.2 million from fiscal 2012 due primarily to the decrease in net sales.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S7	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the APAC segment decreased $13.8 million, or 1.2 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013, primarily due to a $166.8 million decrease in net sales resulting from the disengagement of Juniper.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S8	Partially offsetting this decrease was an increase in net sales of $82.9 million to one of our larger networking/communications customers as a result of new product ramps and an increase in net sales of $61.8 million to two of our larger healthcare/life sciences customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S9	Operating income increased $19.2 million in fiscal 2014 as compared to fiscal 2013, primarily as a result of favorable changes in customer mix and supply chain productivity.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S10	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the APAC segment increased $35.9 million, or 3.2 percent, from fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S11	The increase in net sales was primarily experienced in the healthcare/life sciences sector as a result of new program wins which more than offset the $14.2 million decrease in sales to Juniper as a result of its disengagement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S12	Operating income increased $14.4 million in fiscal 2013 as compared to fiscal 2012, primarily as a result of the increase in net sales and favorable changes in customer mix combined with higher costs incurred in fiscal 2012 related to facility expansion and the Kontron arrangement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P26_S13	Net sales for fiscal 2014 in the EMEA segment decreased $6.6 million, or 5.4 percent, as compared to fiscal 2013, due primarily to the disengagement of two customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	current year as compared to the prior year due to increased fixed manufacturing expenses in both Oradea, Romania and the U.K., resulting from increased depreciation and personnel expenses associated with facility investments.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2013 in the EMEA segment increased $27.1 million, or 28.4 percent, from fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	The increase in net sales was driven primarily by approximately $22.0 million from the ramp of new customers in each of our market sectors, partially offset by decreased net sales of $8.5 million due to the disengagement of an industrial/commercial customer.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S2	Operating loss increased in fiscal 2013 as compared to fiscal 2012 due to an increase in fixed costs associated with the new facility in Oradea, Romania and the ramping of new customers in the U.K.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S3	An increase in labor and parts costs in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2013 also contributed to the increased operating loss.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S4	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES Cash and cash equivalents were $346.6 million as of September 27, 2014 as compared to $341.9 million as of September 28, 2013 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S5	Cash generated from operations and stock option exercises in fiscal 2014 was substantially offset by cash used for capital expenditures primarily related to facility investments, purchases of common stock as part of our stock repurchase program, and capital lease payments.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S6	As of September 27, 2014 , 90.9 percent of our cash and cash equivalents balance was held outside of the U.S. by our foreign subsidiaries.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S7	Certain foreign countries impose taxes and overall penalties on transfers of cash; however, our intent is to permanently reinvest funds held in these countries.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S8	If this cash were remitted to the U.S., additional tax obligations may result that would reduce the amount of cash ultimately available to us in the U.S.
785786_14_ITEM7_P28_S9	Currently, we believe that cash held in the U.S., together with cash available under U.S. credit facilities and cash provided by operating activities, will be sufficient to meet our U.S. liquidity needs for the next twelve months and for the foreseeable future.
785786_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	The following table provides a summary of cash flows for fiscal 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , excluding the effect of exchange rates on cash and cash equivalents (in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	Cash flows provided by operating activities were $88.4 million for fiscal 2014 , as compared to cash flows provided by operating activities of $207.6 million for fiscal 2013 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	The decrease was primarily attributable to the increase in net sales, which resulted in higher inventory and accounts receivable balances at the end of fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	Additionally, increases in forecasted net sales for the first quarter of fiscal 2015 relative to the first quarter of fiscal 2014 also resulted in higher inventory and accounts payable balances at the end of fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S3	Cash flows provided by operating activities were $207.6 million for fiscal 2013 , as compared to cash flows provided by operating activities of $157.5 million for fiscal 2012 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S4	Cash flows provided by operating activities increased due to overall improved working capital management.
785786_14_ITEM7_P30_S5	The following table provides a summary of cash cycle days for the periods indicated (in days):
785786_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	We calculate days in accounts receivable as accounts receivable for the respective quarter divided by annualized sales for the respective quarter by day.
785786_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	We calculate days in inventory, accounts payable, and cash deposits as each balance sheet line item for the respective quarter divided by annualized cost of sales for the respective quarter by day.
785786_14_ITEM7_P31_S2	We calculate annualized cash cycle as the sum of days in accounts receivable and days in inventory, less days in accounts payable and days in cash deposits.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	Days in accounts receivable for the three months ended September 27, 2014 decreased five days compared to the three months ended September 28, 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S1	The decrease is primarily attributable to new product ramps related to a key customer with shorter payment terms than our other customers.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S2	Days in inventory for the three months ended September 27, 2014 increased eight days compared to the three months ended September 28, 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S3	The increase is primarily attributable to the timing of inventory build-up to support forecasted net sales.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S4	Days in accounts payable for the three months ended September 27, 2014 increased four days compared to the three months ended September 28, 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S5	The improvement was primarily attributable to increased purchases from suppliers with more favorable terms to support increases in net sales.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S6	Days in cash deposits for the three months ended September 27, 2014 decreased four days compared to the three months ended September 28, 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S7	The decrease was primarily attributable to the return of approximately $11.0 million of excess deposit funds to Juniper in the first quarter of fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P32_S8	As of September 27, 2014 cash cycle days increased three days compared to September 28, 2013 due to the factors discussed above.
785786_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	Free cash flow ( FCF ), which we define as cash flow provided by (used in) operations less capital expenditures, was $23.1 million for fiscal 2014, as compared to $99.5 million for fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	The decrease of $76.4 million from fiscal 2013 was primarily attributable to the decrease in cash provided by operating activities, partially offset by a reduction in capital expenditures, which is discussed below.
785786_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	Non-GAAP financial measures, including FCF, are used for internal management assessments because such measures provide additional insight into ongoing financial performance.
785786_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	In particular, we provide FCF because we believe it offers insight into the metrics that are driving management decisions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P34_S2	We view FCF as an important financial metric as it demonstrates our ability to generate cash and allows us to pursue opportunities that enhance shareholder value.
785786_14_ITEM7_P34_S3	FCF is a non-GAAP financial measure which should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, measures of our financial performance prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP.

785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	The reduction was due to decreases in capital expenditures, which were $65.3 million in fiscal 2014 compared to $108.1 million in fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	This decrease was primarily attributable to a facility investment at one location (Guadalajara, Mexico) during fiscal 2014, relative to facility investments at three locations during fiscal 2013 (Xiamen, China; Oradea, Romania; and Neenah, Wisconsin).
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	Cash flows used in investing activities for fiscal 2013 increased to $107.2 million from $92.2 million in fiscal 2012 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S4	Cash flows used in investing activities increased primarily due to the additional investments in footprint expansions, partially offset by payments for business acquisitions in the prior period, including the Kontron arrangement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S5	We utilized available cash and operating cash flows as the sources for funding our operating requirements during fiscal 2014 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S6	We currently estimate capital expenditures for fiscal 2015 will be approximately $50.0 million.
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S7	Cash flows used in financing activities were $21.0 million for fiscal 2014 , as compared to cash flows used in financing activities of $57.4 million for fiscal 2013 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S8	The decrease was primarily attributable to lower common stock repurchase activity in fiscal 2014 relative to fiscal 2013, as well as term loan repayments in fiscal 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S9	The decrease was further enhanced by the effect of higher stock option exercise activity in fiscal 2014 relative to fiscal 2013 due to more favorable market conditions during fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P35_S10	Cash flows used in financing activities totaled $57.4 million for fiscal 2013, as compared to cash flows used in financing activities of $10.8 million for fiscal 2012.
785786_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	Cash flows used in financing activities for fiscal 2012 were comprised primarily of payments on debt, partially offset by debt proceeds and proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
785786_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	On August 13, 2014, the Board of Directors authorized a stock repurchase program under which the Company is authorized to repurchase up to $30.0 million of its common stock in fiscal 2015.
785786_14_ITEM7_P36_S2	The Company expects to complete this program on a relatively consistent basis during fiscal 2015.
785786_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	On August 19, 2013, the Board of Directors authorized a stock repurchase program under which the Company was authorized to repurchase up to $30.0 million of its common stock in fiscal 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	During fiscal 2014, the Company repurchased 733,447 shares under this program for $30.0 million , at an average price of $40.90 per share.
785786_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	These shares were recorded as treasury stock.
785786_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	On October 23, 2012, the Board of Directors authorized a stock repurchase program under which the Company was authorized to repurchase up to $50.0 million of its common stock.
785786_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	During fiscal 2013, the Company repurchased 1,821,698 shares under this program for $49.9 million, at an average price of $27.37 per share.
785786_14_ITEM7_P38_S2	These shares were recorded as treasury stock.
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	On May 15, 2014, the Company entered into an amendment (the "Amendment") to its credit agreement, dated as of May 15, 2012 (as amended, the "Credit Agreement"), related to its five-year senior unsecured credit facility (the Credit Facility ).
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	As a result of the Amendment, the Credit Facility, which was formerly a $250.0 million facility consisting of a $160.0 million revolving credit facility and a $90.0 million term loan (balance of $75.0 million as of May 15, 2014), was converted into a $235.0 million revolving credit facility, and its termination date was extended from May 15, 2017 to May 15, 2019.
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	The Credit Facility may potentially be increased by $100.0 million to $335.0 million generally by mutual agreement of the Company and the lenders, subject to certain customary conditions.
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S3	Quarterly principal repayments on the former term loan of $3.8 million per quarter ended on March 28, 2013.
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S4	As of September 27, 2014, the Company had $75.0 million of revolving borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility.
785786_14_ITEM7_P39_S5	During fiscal 2014, the Company borrowed and repaid $281.0 million of revolving borrowings under the Credit Facility.
785786_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	The financial covenants (as defined under the Credit Agreement) require that the Company maintain, as of each fiscal quarter end, a maximum total leverage ratio and a minimum interest coverage ratio.
785786_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	As of September 27, 2014, the Company was in compliance with all financial covenants of the Credit Agreement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	Borrowings under the Credit Facility, at the Company's option, bear interest at a defined base rate or the LIBOR rate plus, in each case, an applicable margin based upon the Company's leverage ratio as defined in the Credit Agreement.
785786_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	Rates would increase upon negative changes in specified Company financial metrics and would decrease to no less than LIBOR plus 1.000% or base rate plus 0.000% upon reduction in the current total leverage ratio.
785786_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	As of September 27, 2014, the Company had a borrowing rate of LIBOR plus 1.125%.
785786_14_ITEM7_P41_S1	As of September 27, 2014, all outstanding debt under the Credit Facility is effectively at a fixed interest rate as a result of the interest rate swap contract discussed in Note 5, "Derivatives and Fair Value Measurements," in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
785786_14_ITEM7_P41_S2	There is no floating rate debt outstanding under the Credit Facility as of September 27, 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P41_S3	The Company is required to pay an annual commitment fee on the unused revolver credit commitment based on the Company's leverage ratio; the fee was 0.175% as of September 27, 2014.
785786_14_ITEM7_P41_S4	The Company also has outstanding 5.20% Senior Notes, due on June 15, 2018 (the "Notes"); $175.0 million principal of the Notes was outstanding as of both September 27, 2014 and September 28, 2013 .
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	The Credit Facility and Note Purchase Agreement allow for the future payment of cash dividends or the future repurchases of shares provided that no event of default (including any failure to comply with a financial covenant) exists at the time of, or would be caused by, the dividend payment or the share repurchases.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	We have not paid cash dividends in the past and do not currently anticipate paying them in the future.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	However, we evaluate from time to time potential uses of excess cash, which in the future may include share repurchases above those already authorized, a special dividend or recurring dividends.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S3	Based on current expectations, we believe that our projected cash flows from operations, available cash and cash equivalents, potential borrowings under the Credit Facility, and our leasing capabilities should be sufficient to meet our working capital and fixed capital requirements for the next twelve months and for the foreseeable future.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S4	If our future financing needs increase, we may need to arrange additional debt or equity financing.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S5	Accordingly, we evaluate and consider from time to time various financing alternatives to supplement our financial resources.
785786_14_ITEM7_P42_S6	However, particularly due to the current uncertainty of the credit and financial markets, we cannot be assured that we will be able to make any such arrangements on acceptable terms.
785786_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Our disclosures regarding contractual obligations and commercial commitments are located in various parts of our regulatory filings.
785786_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	Information in the following table provides a summary of our contractual obligations and commercial commitments as of September 27, 2014 (dollars in millions):
785786_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	1) Includes amounts outstanding under the Credit Facility.
