785786_16_ITEM5_P1_S1	The values on the graph show the relative performance of an investment of $100 made on September 30, 2011, in Plexus common stock and in each of the indices as of the last business day of the respective fiscal year.
785786_16_ITEM5_P2_S0	Shareholders of Record; Dividends As of November 14, 2016, we had 478 shareholders of record.
785786_16_ITEM5_P2_S1	We have not paid any cash dividends in the past.
785786_16_ITEM5_P2_S2	We currently anticipate that in the foreseeable future the majority of earnings will be retained to finance the development of our business and our authorized share repurchases.
785786_16_ITEM5_P2_S3	However, the Company evaluates from time to time potential uses of excess cash, which in the future may include additional share repurchases, a special dividend or recurring dividends.
785786_16_ITEM5_P2_S4	See also Part II, Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources, for a discussion of the Company s intentions regarding dividends, and loan covenants which could restrict dividend payments.
785786_16_ITEM5_P3_S0	The following table provides the specified information about the repurchases of shares by the Company during the three months ended October 1, 2016 :
785786_16_ITEM5_P4_S0	(1) On August 20, 2015, the Board of Directors approved a stock repurchase program under which the Company is authorized to repurchase up to $30.0 million of its common stock during fiscal 2016.
785786_16_ITEM5_P4_S1	The Company repurchased 760,903 shares under this program for $30.0 million at an average price of $39.43 per share.
785786_16_ITEM5_P4_S2	These shares were recorded as treasury stock.
785786_16_ITEM5_P4_S3	On June 6, 2016, the Board of Directors approved a multi-year stock repurchase program under which the Company is authorized to repurchase up to $150.0 million of its common stock beginning in fiscal 2017.
785786_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	(1) During fiscal 2016, the Company recorded $7.0 million in restructuring and other charges and $5.2 million in selling and administrative expenses, which are included in operating income.
785786_16_ITEM6_P0_S1	The $7.0 million was largely related to the Company's closure of its manufacturing facility in Fremont, California, and the partial closure of its Livingston, Scotland facility.
785786_16_ITEM6_P0_S2	The $5.2 million was related to accelerated stock-based compensation expense recorded pursuant to the previously announced retirement agreement with the Company's former Chief Executive Officer.
785786_16_ITEM6_P0_S3	During fiscal 2015 and 2014 the Company recorded $1.7 million and $11.3 million, respectively, of restructuring and other charges, largely related to the Company's consolidation of its manufacturing facilities in Wisconsin, as well as its relocation of manufacturing operations from Juarez, Mexico to Guadalajara, Mexico.
785786_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	No. 2015-17, which requires all deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities to be classified as non-current and ASU No. 2015-03, which requires unamortized debt issuance costs to be presented as a contra liability.
785786_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	The adoptions resulted in decreased total assets of $10.6 million, $7.1 million, $3.5 million and $5.0 million for fiscal 2015, 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
785786_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	Refer to New Accounting Pronouncements in Note 1 - Description of Business and Significant Accounting Policies in the accompanying Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S0	(3) The Company defines return on invested capital ("ROIC"), a non-GAAP financial measure, as tax-effected operating income divided by average invested capital over a rolling five-quarter period.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S1	For a reconciliation of ROIC and Economic Return to our financial statements that were prepared in accordance with GAAP, see Exhibit 99.1 to this annual report on Form 10-K. (4) In fiscal 2012, the Company established a valuation allowance against its U.S. deferred tax assets resulting in an additional tax provision of approximately $20.6 million ($22.8 million provision, offset by $2.2 million recorded to other comprehensive income) and a decrease in diluted earnings per share of $0.64.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S2	Return on invested capital excludes the $20.6 million net deferred tax asset reduction.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S3	An additional $1.3 million of valuation allowance established for fiscal 2012 relates to operating losses in Germany and Romania, making the total valuation allowance for that year $24.1 million.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S4	(5) Fiscal 2015 included 53 weeks.
785786_16_ITEM6_P4_S5	All other periods presented included 52 weeks.
785786_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	OVERVIEW Plexus Corp. and its subsidiaries (together Plexus, the Company, or "we") participate in the Electronic Manufacturing Services ( EMS ) industry.
785786_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	We deliver optimized solutions to our customers through our unique Product Realization Value Stream.
785786_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our customer-focused solutions model seamlessly integrates innovative product conceptualization, design, commercialization, manufacturing, fulfillment and sustaining solutions.
785786_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Plexus delivers comprehensive end-to-end solutions for customers in the Americas ( AMER ), Europe, Middle East, and Africa ( EMEA ) and Asia-Pacific ( APAC ) regions.
785786_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	We provide award-winning customer service to more than 140 branded product companies in the Healthcare/Life Sciences, Industrial/Commercial, Networking/Communications and Defense/Security/Aerospace market sectors.
785786_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	Our customers have stringent quality, reliability and regulatory requirements, requiring exceptional production and supply chain agility.
785786_16_ITEM7_P1_S3	Their products require complex configuration management, direct order fulfillment (to end customers) and global logistics management and Aftermarket Services.
785786_16_ITEM7_P1_S4	To service the complexities that our customers' products demand, we utilize our Product Realization Value Stream, addressing our customers' products from concept to end of life.
785786_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The following information should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included herein and Risk Factors included in Part I, Item 1A herein.
785786_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Consolidated Performance Summary.
785786_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	The following table presents selected consolidated financial data for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 (dollars in millions, except per share data):
785786_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 decreased $98.3 million , or 3.7% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	The net sales decrease was primarily the result of a $247.4 million decrease in net sales in the Networking/Communications sector, which was partially offset by increased net sales of $88.7 million, $30.3 million and $30.1 million in the Industrial/Commercial, Defense/Security/Aerospace and Healthcare/Life Sciences sectors, respectively.
785786_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	Net sales for fiscal 2015 increased $276.0 million, or 11.6%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P4_S3	The net sales increase was primarily the result of increases across all market sectors.
785786_16_ITEM7_P4_S4	The most significant net sales increases were from the Industrial/Commercial and Networking/Communications sectors, which increased by $102.0 million and $82.0 million, respectively.
785786_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our net sales by market sector for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 were as follows (in millions):
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the Healthcare/Life Sciences sector increased $30.1 million , or 4.0% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	The increase was primarily due to a $41.9 million increase in net sales due to the ramp of various new programs for several existing customers, $26.4 million from the ramp of production for three new customers and a net increase in end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	Partially offsetting the increases were decreases in net sales of $20.3 million due to three customers bringing the manufacturing process for four programs in house, $7.0 million due to two customer disengagements and $5.5 million due to a product disengagement with a customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S3	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the Healthcare/Life Sciences sector increased $52.9 million, or 7.6%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S4	The increase was primarily due to $39.6 million of new program ramps for one customer, increased end-market demand and new program ramps across several other customers in this sector.
785786_16_ITEM7_P6_S5	The increase was partially offset by a program loss for one customer, which resulted in a decrease of $14.6 million, and decreased net sales to several other customers as a result of program ramp downs and decreased end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the Industrial/Commercial sector increased $88.7 million , or 12.9% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	The increase was primarily due to ramps of production for a major customer, which resulted in increased net sales of $221.2 million.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	Partially offsetting the increase were decreases of $42.7 million related to the previously announced disengagement of a customer, $30.2 million that resulted from two customers revising their business models as a result of decreased end-market demand and $12.4 million due to pilot programs for three customers not transitioning into the production stage.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	The remaining decrease was due to decreased customer end-market demand, due in part to the downturn in the oil and gas markets.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the Industrial/Commercial sector increased $102.0 million, or 17.5%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S5	The increase was primarily due to a $45.6 million increase in net sales to a new customer in fiscal 2015, a $36.8 million increase related to new programs with existing customers, a $24.4 million increase related to new customers secured in fiscal 2014 that ramped in fiscal 2015, and several other customers with increased end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P7_S6	These increases were partially offset by a $22.1 million decrease due to the disengagement of a customer as a result of the inability to reach contractual terms, and several other customers with decreased end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the Networking/Communications sector decreased $247.4 million , or 29.3% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	The reduction in net sales was primarily driven by a $90.7 million decrease in net sales due to a previously announced program disengagement, a $75.8 million decrease in net sales to another customer that resulted from decreased end-market demand for one of its products and a $29.2 million decrease due to the disengagement of a customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	Overall decreased end-market demand drove the remaining reduction in net sales during the year.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S3	Partially offsetting the decreases was a $10.2 million increase in net sales due to the ramp of production of new programs for two existing customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S4	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the Networking/Communications sector increased $82.0 million, or 10.8%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S5	The change was primarily the result of a $50.1 million increase in net sales to a key customer as a result of increased end-market demand, a $36.1 million increase in net sales from one of our largest customers as a result of new product ramps and expansion of its end-market demand, and a $16.0 million increase related to a new customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S6	Additionally, five customers' net sales increased $37.5 million, in aggregate, primarily as a result of increased end-market demand as well as new program ramps.
785786_16_ITEM7_P8_S7	These increases were partially offset by a $19.8 million decrease due to a customer that experienced softening in its end-market demand, a $10.6 million decrease related to a customer disengagement and several other customers with decreased end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the Defense/Security/Aerospace sector increased $30.3 million , or 8.1% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	The improvement was primarily attributable to increased net sales of $43.2 million that resulted from the ramp of production of new programs for several existing customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $6.9 million due to program disengagements with two customers as well as a net decrease in customer end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the Defense/Security/Aerospace sector increased $39.2 million, or 11.7%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	The increase was primarily driven by new program ramps and increased end-market demand spread among multiple customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	As a percentage of consolidated net sales, net sales attributable to customers representing 10% or more of consolidated net sales as well as the percentage of net sales attributable to our ten largest customers for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , were as follows:
785786_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	Cost of sales for fiscal 2016 decreased $86.1 million , or 3.6% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Cost of sales is comprised primarily of material and component costs, labor costs, and overhead.
785786_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	During fiscal 2016 and 2015 , approximately 90.0% of the total cost of sales was variable in nature and fluctuated with sales volumes.
785786_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	Of this amount, approximately 88.0% of these costs were related to material and component costs.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	As a result of using a cost-plus markup pricing arrangement with our customers, changes in costs typically result in corresponding changes in price, which generally results in an immaterial impact on gross profit.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	Therefore, as expected, the decrease in cost of sales of 3.6% as compared to fiscal 2015 was generally in line with the 3.7% decrease in net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	Cost of sales decreased slightly less than the decrease in net sales primarily due to a $2.9 million increase in cost of sales that resulted from losses sustained from a typhoon that impacted the Company's manufacturing facilities in Xiamen, China during the fiscal 2016 fourth quarter.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	Cost of sales for fiscal 2015 increased $262.1 million , or 12.2% , as compared to fiscal 2014 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S4	The increase in cost of sales of 12.2% was generally in line with the 11.6% increase in net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S5	The increase in cost of sales as compared to the net sales increase in fiscal 2015 was primarily due to increased salary and wages expense in a Defense/Security/Aerospace focus factory resulting from additional direct and fixed labor resources in our cost structure to improve quality and delivery for some of our customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S6	Direct labor costs increased by $1.8 million in fiscal 2015 due in large part to the employee mix shifting from temporary to permanent labor resources.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S7	In fiscal 2015, we also incurred an additional $1.7 million in consulting fees to bring temporary, experienced quality inspectors in to enhance our manufacturing processes.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S8	Finally, an additional $4.5 million of fixed labor resources were added throughout fiscal 2015 to provide support for manufacturing and quality control for the more complex assemblies and processes in the sector.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S9	Gross profit for fiscal 2016 decreased $12.2 million , or 5.1% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S10	Gross margin decreased 10 basis points as compared to fiscal 2015.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S11	The primary driver of the decreases in gross profit and gross margin as compared to fiscal 2015 was the decrease in net sales and the $2.9 million increase in cost of sales due to the typhoon-related losses previously discussed.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S12	Gross profit for fiscal 2015 increased $14.0 million, or 6.2%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S13	Gross profit increased $28.4 million primarily as a result of increased sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S14	This was partially offset by a $14.4 million increase in fixed costs primarily in the AMER region as a result of continued investments in our then-new manufacturing facilities in Neenah, Wisconsin and Guadalajara, Mexico and costs incurred related to production process constraints in a Defense/Security/Aerospace focus factory.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S15	Gross margin decreased to 9.0% from 9.5%.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S16	The largest driver of the decrease in gross margin percentage from fiscal 2014 to fiscal 2015 was a lower net parts contribution margin and lower labor contribution margin due to increased labor expenses previously discussed.
785786_16_ITEM7_P13_S17	These decreases were partially offset by lower fixed costs as a percentage of net sales that resulted primarily from better leveraged fixed costs.
785786_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	Operating income for fiscal 2016 decreased $16.0 million as compared to fiscal 2015 as a result of the decrease in gross profit previously discussed and a $5.3 million increase in restructuring and other charges, partially offset by a $1.5 million reduction in selling and administrative expenses ("S A").
785786_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Restructuring and other charges were higher in fiscal 2016 largely due to the closure of our manufacturing facility in Fremont, California and the partial closure of our Livingston, Scotland facility to align with reduced end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	The reduction in S A resulted from a $6.4 million decrease in variable compensation expense, which was partially offset by a $5.4 million increase in stock-based compensation expense primarily due to $5.2 million of accelerated stock-based compensation expense related to modifications of awards held by the Company's former President and Chief Executive Officer in connection with his retirement.
785786_16_ITEM7_P14_S3	Operating margin decreased to 3.9% in fiscal 2016 from 4.3% in fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Operating income for fiscal 2015 increased $14.8 million as compared to fiscal 2014 as a result of the increase in gross profit previously discussed and a $9.6 million decrease in restructuring and other charges, which were higher in fiscal 2014 because they largely related to the consolidation of manufacturing facilities in Wisconsin, and the relocation of manufacturing operations from Juarez, Mexico to Guadalajara.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	This was partially offset by an $8.7 million increase in S A primarily due to increased variable compensation expense, higher compensation expense due to increased headcount and an increase in professional services expense.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	Operating margin increased to 4.3% for fiscal 2015 from 4.2% for fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S3	Other expense for fiscal 2016 increased $2.9 million as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S4	The increase in other expense for fiscal 2016 was primarily the result of a $3.0 million increase in foreign exchange losses that resulted from foreign exchange volatility.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S5	Other expense for fiscal 2015 increased $1.9 million as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S6	The increase in other expense for fiscal 2015 was primarily the result of a $1.7 million increase in interest expense due to higher average borrowings, a $0.8 million increase in miscellaneous expense due to fiscal 2014 having benefited from a favorable non-recurring accrual related to the termination of an agreement for additional land in Hangzhou, China, and an additional $1.4 million increase in other miscellaneous expenses.
785786_16_ITEM7_P15_S7	This was partially offset by a $1.4 million increase in foreign exchange gains and a $0.6 million increase in interest income due to an increase of cash and cash equivalents.
785786_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	Income tax expense and effective annual income tax rates for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 were as follows (dollars in millions):
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Income tax expense for fiscal 2016 was $11.0 million compared to $12.0 million for fiscal 2015 and $6.1 million for fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	The Company's annual effective tax rates vary from the U.S. statutory rate of 35.0% primarily as a result of the mix of earnings from U.S. and foreign jurisdictions and a tax holiday granted to a subsidiary located in the APAC region where the Company derives a significant portion of its earnings.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S2	The effective tax rate for fiscal 2016 was higher than the effective tax rate for fiscal 2015 primarily as a result of the overall decrease in income before taxes in jurisdictions where the Company does not pay taxes.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S3	The effective tax rate for fiscal 2015 was higher than the effective rate for fiscal 2014 primarily as a result of the geographic distribution of worldwide earnings and tax benefits of $3.8 million primarily due to the lapse of statute of limitations related to certain U.S. tax examinations during fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S4	During fiscal 2016, the Company repatriated $100.0 million of current year foreign earnings from the APAC region to the U.S., which had no income statement impact due to U.S. net operating losses, the use of U.S. tax credits and the reversal of the related valuation allowance.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S5	The repatriation does not impact the permanently reinvested assertions made by the Company regarding prior period foreign earnings as the remittance was distributed exclusively from current year foreign earnings.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S6	The Company does not have a history of repatriating foreign earnings by way of a taxable dividend and considers the fiscal 2016 remittance to be an isolated occurrence.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S7	The Company does not anticipate a similar repatriation in the foreseeable future.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S8	The Company has been granted a tax holiday for a foreign subsidiary operating in the APAC region.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S9	This tax holiday will expire on December 31, 2024, and is subject to certain conditions with which the Company expects to comply.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S10	The Company benefited from a second tax holiday within the APAC region until December 31, 2013, when it expired under the terms of the Company's agreement with the local taxing authority.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S11	In fiscal 2016, 2015 and 2014, these holidays resulted in tax reductions of approximately $27.1 million ($0.81 per basic share), $29.9 million ($0.89 per basic share), and $24.1 million ($0.71 per basic share), respectively.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S12	See also Note 6, "Income Taxes," in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information regarding the Company's tax rate.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S13	The annual effective tax rate for fiscal 2017 is expected to be approximately 9.0% to 11.0%.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S14	Net income for fiscal 2016 decreased $17.9 million , or 19.0% , to $76.4 million from fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S15	Net income decreased primarily as a result of decreased gross profit, increased restructuring and other charges and increased foreign exchange losses, partially offset by decreases in S A and income tax expense, as discussed previously.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S16	Net income for fiscal 2015 increased $7.1 million, or 8.2%, to $94.3 million from fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P17_S17	Net income increased primarily as a result of increased gross profit and lower restructuring and other charges, partially offset by increases in S A, interest expense and income tax expense, as discussed previously.
785786_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Diluted earnings per share decreased to $2.24 in fiscal 2016 from $2.74 in fiscal 2015 primarily as a result of decreased net income.
785786_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	This was partially offset by the positive impact of fewer weighted average outstanding shares in fiscal 2016 due to our common stock repurchase program.
785786_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	See Note 13, "Shareholders' Equity," in Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information regarding the Company's stock repurchase programs.
785786_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Diluted earnings per share increased to $2.74 for fiscal 2015 from $2.52 for fiscal 2014 primarily as a result of increased net income.
785786_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	Further improvement was attributable to the positive impact of fewer weighted average outstanding shares in fiscal 2015 due to our common stock repurchase program.
785786_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	Return on Invested Capital ( ROIC ) and Economic Return.
785786_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	We use a financial model that is aligned with our business strategy and includes a ROIC goal of 500 basis points over our weighted average cost of capital ( WACC ), which we refer to as Economic Return, and a 4.7% to 5.0% operating margin target.
785786_16_ITEM7_P20_S2	Our primary focus is on our Economic Return goal of 5.0%, which is designed to create shareholder value and generate sufficient cash to self-fund our targeted organic revenue growth rate of 12.0%.
785786_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	ROIC and Economic Return are non-GAAP financial measures.
785786_16_ITEM7_P21_S1	Non-GAAP financial measures, including ROIC and Economic Return, are used for internal management goals and decision making because such measures provide management and investors additional insight into financial performance.
785786_16_ITEM7_P21_S2	In particular, we provide ROIC and Economic Return because we believe they offer insight into the metrics that are driving management decisions because we view ROIC and Economic Return as important measures in evaluating the efficiency and effectiveness of our long-term capital requirements.
785786_16_ITEM7_P21_S3	We also use a derivative measure of ROIC as a performance criteria in determining certain elements of compensation.
785786_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	We define ROIC as tax-effected operating income before restructuring and other special items divided by average invested capital over a rolling five-quarter period for the fiscal year.
785786_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	Invested capital is defined as equity plus debt, less cash and cash equivalents.
785786_16_ITEM7_P22_S2	Other companies may not define or calculate ROIC in the same way.
785786_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	ROIC and other non-GAAP financial measures should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, measures of our financial performance prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ).
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	We review our internal calculation of WACC annually.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S1	Our WACC was 11.0% for fiscal years 2016 , 2015 and 2014 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S2	By exercising discipline to generate ROIC in excess of our WACC, our goal is to create value for our shareholders.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S3	ROIC was 13.8% , 14.0% , and 15.2% for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively, and was calculated excluding special items of $15.1 million for fiscal 2016 related to accelerated stock-based compensation expense due to the retirement of our former President and Chief Executive Officer, typhoon-related losses and restructuring and other charges.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S4	Fiscal 2015 and 2014 ROIC was calculated excluding $1.7 million and $11.3 million of restructuring and other charges, respectively.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S5	Fiscal 2016 ROIC of 13.8% reflects an Economic Return of 2.8%, based on our weighted average cost of capital of 11.0%.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S6	For a reconciliation of ROIC, Economic Return and adjusted operating income (tax effected) to our financial statements that were prepared using GAAP, see Exhibit 99.1 to this annual report on Form 10-K, which exhibit is incorporated herein by reference.
785786_16_ITEM7_P24_S7	Refer to the table below, which includes the calculation of ROIC and Economic Return (dollars in millions) for the indicated periods:
785786_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	REPORTABLE SEGMENTS A further discussion of our fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 financial performance by reportable segment is presented below (in millions):
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the AMER segment decreased $60.2 million , or 4.3% , as compared to fiscal 2015 , primarily due to decreased net sales of $75.8 million with a customer that resulted from decreased end-market demand for one of its products, $42.7 million due to a previously announced customer disengagement and $29.2 million due to the disengagement of a customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	The remaining reduction in net sales resulted from decreases of: $17.4 million due to two customers bringing the manufacturing process of three programs in house; $12.4 million due to pilot programs for three customers not transitioning into the production stage; $5.5 million due to a product disengagement with one customer; and a net overall decrease in customer end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S2	Partially offsetting these decreases were increased net sales of $187.3 million due to the ramp of production for a major customer, $59.8 million from the ramp of various new programs for several existing customers and $10.4 million due to the ramp of production for a new customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S3	Operating income for fiscal 2016 decreased $3.7 million, or 5.4%, as compared to fiscal 2015, driven primarily by decreased net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S4	The impact of the net sales decrease was partially offset by a positive change in customer mix due in part to decreased net sales to lower margin customers that resulted from two customer disengagements.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S5	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the AMER segment increased $150.8 million, or 12.2%, as compared to fiscal 2014, primarily due to a then-new Industrial/Commercial sector customer that ramped during fiscal 2015, which contributed $45.6 million in sales, and a $37.2 million increase in net sales from a customer in the Networking/Communications sector as a result of new product ramps and expansion of its end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S6	The remainder of the increase was a result of increased end-market demand and new product ramps for several of our larger customers across the Industrial/Commercial and Healthcare/Life Sciences sectors.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S7	These increases were partially offset by the disengagement of a customer due to the inability to reach contractual terms, which resulted in a $22.1 million decrease.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S8	There was also a $19.8 million decrease due to a customer that experienced softening in its end-market demand, a $14.6 million decrease due to the loss of a customer program, and softening end-market demand for several customers, particularly in the Networking/Communications sector.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S9	During fiscal 2015, production of a Healthcare/Life Sciences customer was transferred from the AMER segment to the APAC segment, which resulted in a decrease of $8.4 million (sales to this customer increased by $47.0 million in the APAC segment, as noted below).
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S10	Operating income for fiscal 2015 decreased $10.6 million from fiscal 2014 primarily due to continued investments in our new manufacturing facilities in Neenah and Guadalajara and costs related to production process constraints in a focus factory for our Defense/Security/Aerospace sector, partially offset by the impact of the increase in net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S11	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the APAC segment decreased $124.0 million , or 9.6% , as compared to fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S12	The reduction in net sales was primarily driven by a $90.7 million decrease in net sales due to a previously announced program disengagement.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S13	Net sales also declined by $30.2 million due to two customers revising their business models as a result of decreased end-market demand and $7.0 million due to two customer disengagements.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S14	The remaining decrease in net sales was due to a net decrease in customer end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S15	These decreases were partially offset by increased net sales of $76.5 million from the ramp of new programs for three existing customers and $19.4 million from the ramp of production for two new customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S16	Operating income decreased $4.7 million in fiscal 2016 as compared to fiscal 2015 , primarily as a result of the decrease in net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P26_S17	The impact of the decrease in net sales was partially offset by a positive shift in net sales mix, partially due to a previously announced program disengagement, and a $4.7 million decrease in fixed manufacturing expenses due to cost saving initiatives.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the APAC segment increased $153.4 million, or 13.5%, as compared to fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Net sales increased in all market sectors with the most significant increase in the Networking/Communications sector, including a combined $62.8 million increase for three customers as a result of increased end-market demand and an aggregate $23.9 million increase related to program ramps for two customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	In addition, net sales to one of our largest customers in the Healthcare/Life Sciences sector increased by $47.0 million.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	Operating income increased $24.7 million in fiscal 2015 as compared to fiscal 2014, primarily as a result of the increase in net sales as fixed manufacturing expenses and S A for the segment were relatively stable in fiscal 2015 as compared to 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S4	Net sales for fiscal 2016 in the EMEA segment increased $30.1 million , or 21.5% , as compared to fiscal 2015 , primarily due to a $30.3 million increase in net sales due to the ramp of production of various new programs with several existing customers and $5.0 million from the ramp of production for a new customer.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S5	This was partially offset by a $3.8 million decrease as a result of a customer bringing the manufacturing of a program in house.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S6	The remaining decrease in net sales was due to a net decrease in customer end-market demand.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S7	Operating loss decreased $4.4 million in fiscal 2016 as compared to fiscal 2015 primarily due to the impact of the net sales increase, while fixed costs remained relatively flat.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S8	Net sales for fiscal 2015 in the EMEA segment increased $24.4 million, or 21.1%, as compared to fiscal 2014, primarily due to a combined increase of $18.7 million from three new customers, a $7.3 million increase to a Networking/Communications customer due to improved end-market demand and new product ramps, and increased end-market demand for several other customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S9	This was partially offset by a $7.2 million decrease as a result of end of life products along with the effects of decreased end-market demand for several other customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P27_S10	Operating loss decreased $3.8 million in fiscal 2015 as compared to fiscal 2014 primarily due to the increase in net sales and improved profitability for engineering-related services.
785786_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES Cash and cash equivalents were $433.0 million as of October 1, 2016 as compared to $357.1 million as of October 3, 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	As of October 1, 2016 , 95.7% of our cash and cash equivalents balances were held outside of the U.S. by our foreign subsidiaries.
785786_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	Certain foreign countries impose taxes and overall penalties on transfers of cash.
785786_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	While our intent has been to permanently reinvest the funds held in these countries, from time to time we review and evaluate that strategy, particularly as the percentage of our cash balance held outside the U.S. has increased.
785786_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	During fiscal 2016, the Company repatriated $100.0 million of current year foreign earnings from the APAC region to the U.S., which had no income statement impact due to U.S. net operating losses, the use of U.S. tax credits and the reversal of the related valuation allowance.
785786_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	The repatriation does not impact the permanently reinvested assertions made by the Company regarding prior period foreign earnings as the remittance was distributed exclusively from current year foreign earnings.
785786_16_ITEM7_P30_S2	The Company does not have a history of repatriating foreign earnings by way of a taxable dividend and considers the fiscal 2016 remittance to be an isolated occurrence.
785786_16_ITEM7_P30_S3	The Company does not anticipate a similar repatriation in the foreseeable future.
785786_16_ITEM7_P30_S4	Currently, we believe that cash held in the U.S., together with cash available under our Credit Facility, will be sufficient to meet our U.S. liquidity needs for the next twelve months and for the foreseeable future.
785786_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	The following table provides a summary of cash flows for fiscal 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , excluding the effect of exchange rates on cash and cash equivalents (in millions):
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	Cash flows provided by operating activities were $127.7 million for fiscal 2016 , as compared to $76.6 million for fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	The improvement was primarily due to increased working capital requirements in fiscal 2015 due to the increase in net sales.
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S2	This was partially offset by the larger increase in cash flows received for customer deposits in fiscal 2015 (discussed below) and the decrease in earnings in fiscal 2016.
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S3	Cash flows provided by operating activities were $76.6 million for fiscal 2015 , as compared to cash flows provided by operating activities of $88.4 million for fiscal 2014 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S4	The decrease was primarily attributable to a significant increase in accounts payable for fiscal 2014 and an increase in net sales to customers with longer payment terms, which resulted in higher accounts receivable balances at the end of fiscal 2015.
785786_16_ITEM7_P32_S5	This was partially offset by improvement in cash flows used for inventory as fiscal 2014 had a significant inventory increase due to the timing of our inventory build to support forecasted sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015, coupled with an increase in customer deposits and improved earnings in fiscal 2015.
785786_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	The following table provides a summary of cash cycle days for the periods indicated (in days):
785786_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	We calculate days in accounts receivable as accounts receivable for the respective quarter divided by annualized sales for the respective quarter by day.
785786_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	We calculate days in inventory, accounts payable, and cash deposits as each balance sheet line item for the respective quarter divided by annualized cost of sales for the respective quarter by day.
785786_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	We calculate annualized cash cycle as the sum of days in accounts receivable and days in inventory, less days in accounts payable and days in cash deposits.
785786_16_ITEM7_P34_S3	Days in accounts receivable for the three months ended October 1, 2016 increased five days compared to the three months ended October 3, 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P34_S4	The increase is primarily attributable to increased net sales to customers with longer payment terms and the timing of payments.
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	Days in inventory for the three months ended October 1, 2016 increased two days compared to the three months ended October 3, 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	The increase is primarily driven by the decrease in annualized cost of sales due primarily to the decrease in net sales and relatively flat inventory levels as a result of demand reductions late in the fourth quarter, which did not allow inventory to decrease by year end in line with the net sales decrease.
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S2	Days in accounts payable for the three months ended October 1, 2016 increased one day compared to the three months ended October 3, 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S3	The increase is primarily driven by the decrease in annualized cost of sales due primarily to the decrease in net sales and the timing of purchases.
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S4	Days in cash deposits for the three months ended October 1, 2016 increased one day compared to the three months ended October 3, 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S5	The increase was primarily attributable to an increase in customer deposits primarily due to a deposit received from one customer to offset on-hand inventory.
785786_16_ITEM7_P35_S6	As of October 1, 2016 annualized cash cycle days increased five days compared to October 3, 2015 due to the factors discussed above.
785786_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	We define free cash flow ( FCF ), a non-GAAP financial measure, as cash flow provided by operations less capital expenditures.
785786_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	FCF was $96.6 million for fiscal 2016 compared to $41.5 million for fiscal 2015 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P36_S2	The increase of $55.1 million was primarily attributable to the increase in cash provided by operating activities described above and the reduction in capital expenditures.
785786_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	Non-GAAP financial measures, including FCF, are used for internal management assessments because such measures provide additional insight to investors into ongoing financial performance.
785786_16_ITEM7_P37_S1	In particular, we provide FCF because we believe it offers insight into the metrics that are driving management decisions.
785786_16_ITEM7_P37_S2	We view FCF as an important financial metric as it demonstrates our ability to generate cash and can allow us to pursue opportunities that enhance shareholder value.
785786_16_ITEM7_P37_S3	FCF is a non-GAAP financial measure that should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, measures of our financial performance prepared in accordance with GAAP.
785786_16_ITEM7_P37_S4	A reconciliation of FCF to our financial statements that were prepared using GAAP follows (in millions):

785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S2	Cash flows used in investing activities were $34.7 million for fiscal 2015 compared to $62.6 million for fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S3	The reduction was due to a $30.2 million decrease in capital expenditures primarily related to our facility investment for Guadalajara during fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S4	We utilized available cash and operating cash flows as the sources for funding our operating requirements during fiscal 2016 .

785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S7	The decrease was primarily attributable to the $5.0 million increase in proceeds received from increased stock option exercise activity during fiscal 2016.
785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S8	Cash flows used in financing activities were $26.2 million for fiscal 2015 compared to $21.0 million for fiscal 2014.
785786_16_ITEM7_P38_S9	The increase was primarily attributable to reduced proceeds from stock option exercises during fiscal 2015.

785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	On July 5, 2016, the Company entered into an amendment to the credit agreement (the "Credit Agreement") related to its senior unsecured credit facility (the "Credit Facility").
785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	The amendment increased the maximum commitment under the Credit Facility from $265 million to $300 million, provides a potential additional $200 million increase in borrowing capacity to $500 million with the approval of the lenders, and extended the termination date of the facility from May 15, 2019, to July 5, 2021.
785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	Consistent with the terms of the Credit Facility prior to its amendment, borrowings under the Credit Facility as amended bear interest, at the Company s option, at a eurocurrency or base rate plus, in each case, an applicable interest rate margin based on the Company s then-current leverage ratio (as defined in the Credit Agreement).
785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	As of October 1, 2016 , the borrowing rate under the Credit Agreement was LIBOR plus 1.125% (or 1.648% ).
785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S4	The Company is required to pay an annual commitment fee on the unused revolver credit commitment based on the Company's leverage ratio; the fee was 0.175% as of October 1, 2016 .
785786_16_ITEM7_P40_S5	During fiscal 2016, the highest daily borrowing was $232.0 million , the average daily borrowings were $188.6 million , and the Company borrowed and repaid $625.0 million of revolving borrowings under the Credit Facility.
785786_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	The financial covenants (as defined under the Credit Agreement) require, among other covenants, that the Company maintain, as of each fiscal quarter end, a maximum total leverage ratio and a minimum interest coverage ratio.
785786_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	As of October 1, 2016 , the Company was in compliance with all financial covenants of the Credit Agreement.
785786_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	In fiscal 2011, Plexus issued $175.0 million in principal amount of 5.20% Senior Notes, due on June 15, 2018 (the "Notes").
785786_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	The related Note Purchase Agreement contains certain financial covenants, which include a maximum total leverage ratio, a minimum interest coverage ratio and a minimum net worth test, all as defined in the agreement.
785786_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	As of October 1, 2016 , the Company was in compliance with all such covenants relating to the Notes and the Note Purchase Agreement.
785786_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	The Credit Agreement and the Note Purchase Agreement allow for the future payment of cash dividends or the repurchase of shares provided that no event of default (including any failure to comply with a financial covenant) exists at the time of, or would be caused by, the dividend payment or the share repurchases.
785786_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	We have not paid cash dividends in the past and do not currently anticipate paying them in the future.
785786_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	However, we evaluate from time to time potential uses of excess cash, which in the future may include share repurchases above those already authorized, a special dividend or recurring dividends.
785786_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	On October 4, 2016, the Company entered into a Master Accounts Receivable Purchase Agreement (the RPA ) with The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd., New York Branch (the Purchaser ).
785786_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	Pursuant to the RPA, the Company, Plexus Malaysia and one or more additional Plexus subsidiaries that may be designed in the future (each, a Seller ) may sell to the Purchaser up to an aggregate of $100.0 million in accounts receivable owed to such Sellers by specified customers.
785786_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	In exchange, the Purchaser pays a purchase price for each purchased receivable equal to the net face value of the receivable less an agreed upon discount.
785786_16_ITEM7_P44_S3	The facility represented by the RPA is non-committed, meaning that the Company and each other Seller acknowledge that they have not paid a commitment or comparable fee to the Purchaser, and that the Purchaser does not have a continuing obligation to purchase any receivable from any Seller.
785786_16_ITEM7_P44_S4	The Purchaser will pay an agreed-upon servicing fee to each Seller with respect to each purchased receivable sold by such Seller, consistent with common market practices.
785786_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	The RPA contains representations, warranties, covenants, and termination events that are customary for factoring transactions of this type.
785786_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	Based on current expectations, we believe that our projected cash flows provided by operations, available cash and cash equivalents, potential borrowings under the Credit Facility, and our leasing capabilities, should be sufficient to meet our working capital and fixed capital requirements for the next twelve months.
785786_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	If our future financing needs increase, we may need to arrange additional debt or equity financing.
785786_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	Accordingly, we evaluate and consider from time to time various financing alternatives to supplement our financial resources.
785786_16_ITEM7_P46_S3	However, we cannot be assured that we will be able to make any such arrangements on acceptable terms.
785786_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our disclosures regarding contractual obligations and commercial commitments are located in various parts of our regulatory filings.
785786_16_ITEM7_P47_S1	Information in the following table provides a summary of our contractual obligations and commercial commitments as of October 1, 2016 (dollars in millions):
785786_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	1) Includes amounts outstanding under the Credit Facility.
785786_16_ITEM7_P48_S1	As of October 1, 2016 , the outstanding balance was $75.0 million .
785786_16_ITEM7_P48_S2	The amounts listed above include interest; see Note 4 in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.
785786_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	2) Includes $175.0 million in principal amount of Notes.
785786_16_ITEM7_P49_S1	The amounts listed above include interest; see Note 4 in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.
785786_16_ITEM7_P49_S2	3) As of October 1, 2016 , purchase obligations consist primarily of purchases of inventory and equipment in the ordinary course of business.
785786_16_ITEM7_P49_S3	4) As of October 1, 2016 , other long-term obligations on the balance sheet included deferred compensation obligations to certain of our former and current executive officers, as well as other key employees, and an asset retirement obligation.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	We have excluded from the above table the impact of approximately $2.8 million , as of October 1, 2016 , related to unrecognized income tax benefits.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S1	The Company cannot make reliable estimates of the future cash flows by period related to these obligations.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S2	5) As of October 1, 2016 , other long-term obligations not on the balance sheet consisted of guarantees and a commitment for salary continuation and certain benefits in the event employment of one executive officer of the Company is terminated without cause.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S3	Excluded from the amounts disclosed are certain bonus and incentive compensation amounts, which would be paid on a prorated basis in the year of termination.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S4	6) Includes future minimum payments under the base lease agreement in Guadalajara, Mexico.
785786_16_ITEM7_P50_S5	Excludes $20.3 million of future minimum payments under renewal options from 2025 through 2034.
